reviewText:
I'm not big on writing reviews to be honest.

I've only written one to date but this game deserves some attention.

I was very reluctant to purchase this game at first because there has just been so much low budget stuff on steam of late but because I had a little change in my wallet and the fact the game is priced correctly I decided to give it a go.

I have to say I am more than delighted with my purchase.

Trese Brothers have done a fantastic job, both with the game and with their community interaction.

They are a credit to game development and how dlc and support of a game should be managed.

The big guns out there, could learn a thing or two from these guys.

I won't go into the story or key features here as you can read all that from the game store page but I will say that the features they list are correct and the game does what it says.

The squad customization is truly inspiring, if a little daunting at first.
What I mean by that is, you don't have AAA graphics here so the tons of equipment and various skills and talents throw lots of numbers at you instead, which can be the daunting part.
However, given a little time and some missions into the game you start to come to terms with it all and then you can't help but want to play more missions to earn more RP to get that new piece of equipment or unlock that new Templar type.

What I like most about building your Templars though, is the fact that you really feel the difference in the changes you make.
A lot of games fail in that regard, you get excited about a new piece of kit or a skill and it proves totally underwhelming in actual combat. Not so here.
You get a new sword and all of a sudden you're single hit killing those low level Xeno's that used to need two hits.
Crowd control is a thing, and now your Templars are ready for it!

I feel the game also does a good job of satisfying the needs of players who like varying skill levels. I often see the arguments about casual and hardcore gamers now, well to me all games should be capable of supporting both by the use of difficulty levels.
Trese Brothers have added many difficulty options to suit all players and each level has a good description of what it actually does so the player isn't left guessing and trying to figure it out themselves (Yet another thing the Brothers should be commended on).

The game does so much right and the Trese Brothers really have poured love and affection into their game and will continue to do so (for Free, I might add).

*Edit: All of the below minor complaints from me have been patched and fixed and the devs continue to update the game. Brilliant devs and they deserve huge credit for everything they do.*

The very few minor things I disliked or found confusing about the game are already being responded to and were the majority have voiced an opinion are being changed.

Things like the speed of text during cutscenes, I'm slowing down in my old age and I find I am having to rush to read which breaks immersion of the story for me. It confused me because during missions you have to click to forward text and I felt this should be the same for cutscene text.

During the starting missions of the game, before you really know what is going on, you are asked to activate a gate but the switch you use to do this just looks like any other map flavour tile and the fact you can click on it is not immediately obvious.
I lost a few turns here, while thinking to myself, Alright I'm in the area you told me to go to, why isn't something happening? Because you didn't click the switch dumbass. Well it wasn't really that obvious game :D

The open and closed deployment before going into a mission confused me because whenever it said open I was clicking furiously around the screen for some way to take the Templars I wanted into the mission.
Before I finally went to the forums and read that 'open' means you can get a control point in the mission which will allow you to call in more Templars as opposed to actually allowing you to take what you want from the beginning.
And closed meant there would be no control point and what you get is what you have for the full mission. (This is something the devs are addressing and will be updated to allow you to take what Templars you want outside of what is actually needed for the scenario, like an engineer or scout etc).

Lastly the fact you left click on an enemy to see their stats but also left click on an enemy to attack them.
In the later missions of the game it is important to watch your Templars heat and balance moving, damage and other various skills.
So I often want to check the health left on an enemy to be sure I can kill it in another way before taking a shot with the same Templar again.
The current system can lead to mistakenly taking shots or using a skill you did not want to.
You can unselect your Templar or their skill before clicking on an enemy to avoid this but I feel it is a little clunky and could do with being changed.

As I said, these things are already been looked into by the Trese Brothers and overall I think they did an amazing job with this game.

I definitely recommend this game to anyone who loves Turn based strategy and squad building games and if you are new to the series and just dipping your toe in I couldn't fault you starting here.

Well worth a purchase.

I hope when the Trese Brothers grow into producing AAA titles they remain true to their current values and continue to price their games correctly and support them as they do now.

Thank you Trese Brothers.

I look forward to what I hope will be a very long and bright future for you in video games.

reviewText:
Absolutely phenomenal turn based combat game. Templar Battleforce is a love letter to games like Space Hulk and the early days of X-COM.

You play as a group of superhuman, genetically enhanced warriors who are protecting a newly colonized section of a vast interstellar empire. Imbued with the ancestoral memories of your templar ancestors, it is your duty to beat back the unreleting hordes (and they really are hordes) of Xenos scum looking to make a meal of you.

Gameplay consists of top-down, turn based combat. You command a small squad of templars in a manner very similar to the original X-COM. Unlike your crysalid-bait rookies, (and more like Space Hulk) your templars have tremendously powerful skills and infinite ammo. The downside is that both abilities and weapons generate heat, as does movement, forcing you to pick which targets to kill, but to decide when as well. Overwatching a bridge swarming with xenos may provide excellent fire support, but the resulting weaponsfire may also overheat your critically toatsy templar.

Also like Space Hulk, you are always completely and totally outnumbered in Templars Battleforce. Enemy reinforcements are infinite, and many battles are fighting advances or retreats against mounting waves of foes. This makes for some surprisingly intense combat, and will definitely give your grey matter a workout. Do you split your forces into two advancing teams to get to the objectives faster? Do you leave one behind at the beacon to wait for your own reinforcements? Do you hold at the beacon until you are at full strength and hope it is sufficient to beat back the mass of xenos that have arrived?

The game also rewards quick mission times with greater experience, giving incentive to take risks. However, your troops are persistent, as is death. Don't spend your Templars unwisely.

TLDR:

If you're a fan of Space Hulk, X-Com, or Turn-based Strategy, you can't go wrong with Templars Battleforce.

reviewText:
Trese Brothers Rising
Templar Battleforce is a polished indie turn-based squad tactics game with base building and RPG elements, set in the Trese Brothers' original Star Traders universe. It's a great game by a great developer. The Trese Brothers, long-time veterans of tabletop tactics games, got their start developing games for smartphones.  They have since produced numerous games exploring multiple genres in a short handful of years. Templar Battleforce represents a return to their stated mission: the creation of high-quality, multi-platform RPGs and Strategy games, supported by strong community involvement and a commitment to lifelong game updates.  All of their games fulfill this vision in some manner, but Templar Battleforce checks every box.  Furthermore, in creating Templar Battleforce, the Trese Brothers have used the lessons learned over their first few years as a fledgling studio to re-envision and re-invent the spirit of one of their earliest games- Templar Assault. It's a great feeling to play a game that is an indie dev's dream made real.

A Different Grim, Dark Future
Before I discuss gameplay I'd like to address a common criticism of both the Star Traders universe and the Steel universe (Trese Brothers' fantasy setting).  The Trese Brothers have time and again explicitly recognized the Warhammer and WH40K settings as major inspirations for their work.  They also acknowledge many other sources of inspiration for their original settings.  Are the Trese Brothers' settings derivative? Yes. Does that make their settings rip-offs? No.  Point me if you can to a fantasy or spce opera setting in a game that is not derivative, because I've never seen it.

The Trese Brothers settings combine common tropes in original and compelling ways, building an internally consistent universe on the foundation of inspiration.  Yes, some devs cut & paste together bits and pieces from popular settings.  The result is a lazy pastiche of improbable bedfellows, without depth or heart.  The Trese Brothers are clearly heavily invested in their settings, and as a result the world-building is unique, coherent, and immersive.

Every Leviathan Armor is for You, Templar. Which One Will You Make Your Own?
Gameplay is divided into two primary components: missions and combat, and HQ activities.  The game features features a branching storyline that is tense and dramatic without being overbearing.  You will encounter story dialogue during most missions, but it rarely lasts longer than a handful of sentences.  The combat is top-down and grid-based.  Each Templar has a set number of Action Points (AP) and Movement Points (MP) derived from their base attributes.  The bottom of the screen displays an action hotbar, portrait, and HP and Heat bars for the selected Templar. Actions use AP and generate Heat. If MP is available acting will consume that as well, so it's often prudent to move everyone first and then go back have each one act.  If the Heat meter fills the Templar will not be able to use hotbar abilities. If it overfills they will take damage. Luckily, taking no action dramatically cools the armor.  Cover, line of sight, smart ability use, and overwatch are key elements of success.  The math feels polished, precise, fair, and detailed.  Many maps contain multiple main and secondary objectives; you will rarely play a Kill All Enemies" mission.

Between missions you manage your squad at the HQ screen. It looks like a base-building interface but there's actually very little of that.  Instead

Templar Battleforce is a top-down turn based tactical battle game in the form of classics such as the original XCOM with a dash of Warhammer 40k flavour thrown in for good measure.

The game is well balanced in my experience. Enemies generally spawn and behave reasonably, encouraging the player to keep up the pace without being overwhelming- at least on the difficulty I have played so far). Enemies and Templars alike have a wide range of interesting talents to select from, none of which have struck me as redundant so far. The tech tree is expansive and detailed, with missions providing enough unlock points to facilitate experimentation while you find the layout that works best for you. The Templars also feature a system akin to genetic memory that allows for full respec between missions. While flavourful, this also allows you to experiment with a variety of builds without having to worry about making your units suboptimal in the later game or having to maintain more copies of each class than you need.

The developers clearly love their creation and have demonstrated a level of interactivity, responsiveness and support that I find very impressive.

If you like the genre, I absolutely recommend this game.

So, these are my thoughts on this game. I will not go into the gameplay or -mechanics in detail, other reviewers already did that extensively. I bought this game a while ago after noticing it in my steam queue and browsing the reviews (esp. vintoks' and Arkelis' recommendations I found very appealing). Played it for a bit and dropped it for XCOM2. Now I am back at it and that alone should tell you something.

The Good:
+ It's been said before, this is the game Space Hulk wanted to be and failed at.

+ The game is very accessible, I consider myself to be a filthy casual when it comes to squad tactics games and I knew my way around pretty quickly without reading a manual. The tutorial is excellent in that regard and tooltips are really helpful. All the powers/actions are adequately explained and those explanations are easily accessible from all the relevant screens.

+ The game mechanics allow for a very good scaling of the difficulty level. I have only played on normal yet (which isn't too much of a challenge even for me *yet*) but I took a peek at other difficulties and the heat distribution of your armor alone requires more planning on your part on the higher ones.

+ I enjoyed the tactical challenges and diverse missions I have encountered so far and I don't miss the hilariously aggravating RNG of XCOM 2 for one second.

+ Customization of your troopers helps identifying and becoming invested with them, as far as you can get invested in something without a personality (your Captain is the sole exception there, as he actually talks) ;).

+ The ability to - at any point between missions - completely and freely respec any character is brilliant and invites you to experiment without having to start a new character. This is (for me) a serious long term enjoyment factor.

+ Same goes for the diverse equipment options you can unlock for your Templars.

+ Various troop specializations give you a wide variety of tactical options (once you unlock the relevant classes in the requisition tree).

+ The story is nice, if not very surprising or unexpected, especially when you are a 40k aficionado like me.

+ The devs. If you read - for example - the negative reviews, you might have noticed, that each one has a calm, objective comment, addressing key gripes of the reviewer where those where recognizable. Frankly I have yet to see something like that anywhere else on Steam (didn’t do ALL the research here tho, so do not make that into a gospel, please). At the same time there is still tweaking and improving of the game going on, months after the official release. And I am not only talking bugfixes, but also new skins and general improvements lesser people would hide behind a DLC.

The Bad:
Things I didn't like with the game(play) itself, as opposed to outside appearances (see The Ugly). I am struggling with this a bit, since I pretty obviously enjoyed the game so far. Also I haven't finished it yet, but I wanted to get a positive review out as small games really can use those. So I might come back later and add to this here, but for now, this is what I got. As of now, none of them are anything major, just small annoyances:

- While there are secondary objectives to a mission, I haven't yet found a way to actually discover what they are without stumbling across them accidentally on the map. This clashes with the bonus you get for completing a mission in as little time as possible. That may be intentional, but I'd like the opportunity to decide beforehand if my squad should rather try for secondary objectives or speed. As it stands I don't even positively KNOW if there are secondary objectives at all most of the time (mostly there are, I think, but there seems to be no way to know beforehand) and this leads to a tendency to do a mission twice, once to chart the map and once to actually progress the campaign. Again, this might be intentional, but me no likey.

- There are opportunities to pick up loot from containers during a mission. You can recognize those by the coloring of their adjacent fields. This I discovered accidentally, it would have been nice to get a hint towards this in the tutorial. Also it seems there is a limit on how often this works during one mission, because I had times when I had already picked something up and then further containers I came across didn't give me anything (again a little annoying, because of wasted turns to get there). This too would be nice if it was mentioned somewhere, I haven't found a hint in that regard yet.

- Sometimes the dialogue options between the missions don't make it sufficiently clear that picking them will start a certain mission and close off other options.


The Ugly:
- If you are looking for eyecandy, this might not be the game for you. The devs did good (and upgraded it noticeably a short while ago), but it can't hold to current standards. And why should it? It is an Indie game, catering to your tactical needs, graphics are a secondary means to that end at best.

- The soundtrack, yeah same. It is ok, but we are pampered by AAA games in that respect. I personally turned it off after a while and have something playing in the background (I hear all the cool kids do that these days anyway).

- No voiced narrative or characters. It's all reading here. That is no problem for me but it bears mentioning.

- The action, hmm. Action and round based strategy? Yes possible (see XCOM(2)), but imo more of the eyecandy category.

tl;dr:
I enjoyed (and still enjoy) this game a lot. I regard it as a real gem in the huge dungpile of bad games that Steam can be. If you like turn based squad-tactics you should check it out. If you like a 40k-esque setting,  even more so. If you bought Space Hulk and were disappointed by that, buy this game! Seriously!

The price tag is immensely reasonable. I have spent more money on some boardgames I put away after one evening. I already got my money’s worth out of this and am still going.

reviewText:
You there! You like sci-fi? You like turn-based TACTICAL (yess, all caps!) games? You like RPGs with deep customization of characters and squad? You like story-driven scenarios with lots of objectives? You like to have access to the mechanics of the rules? You like all of the above except the sci-fi genre (you prefer goblins and wizards, is that it?)?

Well you have to at LEAST read on.

I've only played 2 missions (2 times the first one, 1 time the second), and let me tell you this : this game is serious stuff!  Now you might say ''Pfff, you barely played the game, how can I give credit to your review?''. Because just browsing through the interface, options, library, menus, tech trees, character sheets, etc., you'll get the feeling you know you like to have from this kind of game. The feeling of satisfaction. The feeling of devotion and attention to details from the devs.  The feeling that you'll spend quality time playing the game. The feeling that your decisions in-game actually matter.  And... the feeling that you won't see much of your family and friends for the next few weeks!

Honestly, I know nothing from the Star Traders universe, but I'm familiar with Warhammer 40k and StarCraft with their space marines. The Templars in this game hits the same chords : who doesn't like hulking machines decked-out in heavy weaponry ready to fire at every alien shenanigans they come by? On a more serious note : the Templars are really well done and diverse.  The lore behind them is also very interesting, and I love how it reflects into actual character customization. In this game, you can respec your Templars at-will between each mission, so you'll never be locked in your choices of character upgrades.  It lets you try different skills without the drawback of having to lvl another character.

What I really like is that information is not hidden. If you haven't noticed yet, I like to look at menus, tooltips and interfaces a lot because to me, these are the things that make or brake games like that.  And the ones found in this game are simple, easy to use and easy to know what is what.  From the font, to the colors used to identify different rolls, to its sound effects, you simply cannot have difficulties navigating through your character sheet, assigning orders and planning your moves.

Now to actual gameplay and features. After only 2 missions in, I see the enormous amount of tactical and strategic plays you'll have to make to succeed in this game.  From using the terrain to your advantage, to capturing Tactical Points to get more reinforcement and supplies, while having to carry out your mission in a timely fashion, this game offers a deep experience.  It let's you take your time to plan out your strategy. Turn by turn, yes, but also before deploying into the actual mission.  You have to select your gear, your talents, your skills, etc.  Because you want to succeed, yes. But you also want to survive.

Templar Battleforce offers a wide selection of game difficulties that will satisfy casual to semi-hardcore to full hardcore players.  Permanent death not your cup of tea? Play easy or normal, where your Templars carry on to other missions if you succeed even if they were defeated in battle.  You like to play with permanent death but don't want to lose everything if you screw up? Demanding and Hard difficulties let you abort and retry your missions without penalty, but you can chose to carry on and accept the death of characters if you succeed the mission.  Then there are harder game modes where decisions are final.  You died? Sorry pal, you are dead.  No turning back.

And finally, the amazing support of the devs.  The devs are real soldiers.  They have placed an Overwatch over their game.  As soon as you ask a question.. BAM! an answer comes right away.  They never seem to overheat.  And they are really dedicated to implement player suggestions into the game.  Browse through the community hub and you'll see. They put out guides, they ask for game files to track stats, they actively participate in discussions, they give interviews and are clear about the future of the game (no DLC), and most importantly, they update the game frequently. The game is even available on mobile platforms and they plan to share saved files eventually.

So by all means, if you hesitate about buying this game, you shouldn't. If you are into tactical turn/squad-based games, you will like it. If you don't like that type of game then.. what are you exactly doing reading about it? :P

reviewText:
Templar Battleforce is a game where you guide your  Space Marines  Templar Knights  through a campaign figthing against  Tyranids  xenos,  heretics  cultists, and... Yes, this is indeed like playing a squad-based Warhammer 40k tactics rpg.

Your Templars are very much like the Space Marines of the Warhammer universe: the enjoyment of slaughter, the willingness to die, and the massive suits of power armor. However, unlike Space Marines, they can be women too. And that's about the only difference.

The story is mediocre, centering around colonizing a new system and fighting off xenos and cultists, but provides a few intersting moments. It is a squad-based tactics rpg though, so story is put on a backburner to the combat, which is... alright.

Combat is by far the better part of the game. Multiple classes, most of which actually do use different tactics and even feel different. The Soldier/Neptune and Berseker/Paladin basically play the same except that Paladins can heal. Scouts move fast and hit with snipers, Engineers can fortify and build turrets, soldiers overwatch, hydras can create lakes of fire to limit enemy movement. All this makes choosing who you use and how you use them an actual challenge, especially in the missions with tight corridors.

Unfortunately, that really is all there is to say about this game. It's an enjoyable play of squad tactics and provides quite a bit of fun. On the harder difficulties, your squad members die permanently, but you can recruit replacements any time, so that makes it pretty pointless. If you enjoy tactics games, this is worth a playthrough, though probably pick it up on sale rather than full price.

reviewText:
Between this and Renowned Explorers, it's been a surprisingly good month for indie strategy/rpg games.
This one has you take control of a squad of super powered troops, think 40k space marines and you'd feel very much at home. You take your squad through turn based missions not unlike Xcom tactical phase or Jagged Alliance (if you remember Laser Squad then that's an even better comparison) and the game uses both an AP and MP system as well as an overheating system (keep running around, firing wildly and using abilities wantonly will quickly overheat a Templar's suit and cook the pilot inside!).

MP+AP might confuse some people at first as AP uses up MP too, but it also allows you to take more complex moves then allowed in say..xcom unless you have a ton of perks. Ex: you can have a Templar throw a grenade for 1AP, fall back with remaining MP then end your turn by using up all your APs into firing action.
Combined with overheating, this means optimal use of your Templars can be trickier then it seems especially in hectic situations. If I'm making it out to be tedious though, rest assured, it isn't. It enhances gameplay and contributes to the feeling you are commanding a squad of walking tanks.


Inbetween missions you unlock equipment, abilities and new Templar classes in a tech tree of sorts as well as levelling up and gearing up your Templars. At first the options are limited as you'd expect, but you quickly start unlocking stuff and your Templars are able to carry more equipment as they level, increasing build flexibility as the game goes on.

The game can be played with ironman settings and permadeath if desired.

The best points of this game are definitely the squad development which is far more extensive then any other title of this genre I've played and lots of action, you'll quickly rack up hundreds of dead xenos.

As a 40k fan I was quite partial to the design and feel of the Templars themselves too, a couple of missions has human enemies and/or allies and the difference between normal squishy humans and your power armored behemoths is quite satisfying.

Graphics is probably going to be the biggest barrier for people who care about that. Visuals are perfectly serviceable and clear and I like the blood splatter and gooey messes aliens leave, or for that matter the bloodied wrecks of dead Templars, but I recognize that people born a lot later then me might have more picky tastes so check out screenshots and see if that doesn't bother you.

Pros:
-Exelent rpg mechanics and squad development mechanics, so many games have the rpg tag yet have rather shallow level up mechanics and this isn't one of them. Tooling up your templars is just a joy in this.
-Linked to the above, you can respect stats and talents any time, so no fear of making bad" builds and you can experiment more.
-Missions are nicely varied in the objectives and challenges you need to overcome.

Cons:

reviewText:
This game takes one part Warhammer 40K and one part X-COM and mixes them well. Do not let the dated graphics put you off. The game has a depth to it that you would not expect if you judge it by its looks alone.

While not evenly polished, the game is quite enjoyable. On normal difficulty, the game will challenge you without becoming overly frustrating. There are a couple of levels that add speical objectives that are difficult to achieve either due to time constraints or due to the sheer amount of enemies that come after you. Others, such as the final battle, put your units in situations that make it very difficult to keep them from being overrun and torn apart before you can get backup to them.

All of the unit types are useful in combat, which is something that other games do not do well. Your engineers can hold their own, the scouts are death dealing glass cannons that can save your units from ambushes through their ability to scan around corners, and the hand-to-hand units deal and absorb damage with a flare that put a smile on my face. The later units tend to be a little too similar to their predecessors, and tend to have weaknesses that offset their heightened powers to the point that you are better off investing in boosting the older unit types rather than spend precious research points on the newer units.

While it might seem that I am being harsh in my review, it is because there were so few flaws in the game that they stand out like proud nails on an otherwise unblemished floor. I give this game my full recommendation, if you like either Warhammer 40K or X-COM. If you like both, I think you are in for an unexpected treat.

reviewText:
I really like this game a lot. I think that there are a few things that are off, but it's really enjoyable to play. I also respect that there have been so many patches and additions. There are a couple things that are kinda like...what? otherwise a very good game.

It's tactical and turn based. It's heavily reminiscent of Warhammer 40K so if you're a fan of that you might like this, or hate it depending on how much you like warhammer. The plot is simple. you're a templar dood who takes command of a squad. You're trying to locate the source of xeno scum and wipe them out, essentially.

The turn based combat seems a little weird at first, but once you understand how it works it can work pretty well. You spend AP by doing actions or you spend move points by moving. if you move first, you don't spend action points, but if you shoot first you spend move points. Like if you have 6 move and action points. You move 3 spaces and then shoot for 3 action points. You would have 3 action points and no move points left. This means it's often better to stand firm and fire a whole bunch and encourages stationary combat. Which is good as well because the enemy is mostly melee. There are defintiely ranged enemies too though and there aren't just xenos, but they are the main enemy.

There's also a 'heat' system where if you take too many actions your templar can overheat and take damage. This restricts you from shooting and moving too much.

I feel as though the 'requisition' system is neat too, but kinda makes me spread too thin. It's better to focus on a few classes, like 4 of them than to try and get them all. I also don't like that there is soldier and then heavy weapons because they function essentially the same. Paladin and berserker are similar too, but they have the distinction of being a healer and a pure melee which is nice, but there could be more variety in them.

The other classes are pretty varied though and quite fun to mess with. I like that engineers can lay turrets or specialize in capturing. Scouts can kite or be big hitters and armor penetrators or dedicated stealth scouts. Stealth works pretty uniquely too since it's not just 'turn invisible now you're invisible' but that you increase your stealth and stealth levels make you harder to detect. The only downside I can see is it's hard to tell if your guy is actually 'stealthed' since stealth levels reduce the range the enemy can detect you at. You kinda gotta manually do it?


Anyway I would definitely recommend the game. I like the game, the devs seem responsive in fixing bugs and adding in some content and making the game as a whole better. Some real love was put into the game and it makes the game even better as a result. I would like to see another templar game come out!

reviewText:
You can read a compared review with Ultimate Space Commando here

http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ReviewersGuild/discussions/0/385429125014825200/

Having played Heroes of Steel (previous game by the same developers) I'm going to make a comparison. TBF is much more focused and mostly you aren't going to roam freely around the maps, but it's not a bad thing, since it makes the gaming experience more compact and probably more enjoyable for the average gamer. (In reality you can explore the maps as you wish, but it's dangerous because xenos are costantly spawning and there's a turn limit for XP bonus, if you're trying to obtain it).
Tactical combat and character development are excellent as in HoS, while the tech tree adds a layer of complexity, that makes up for the more linear structure of the game. Feeling of progression is also faster, and so the general pace of the game.
I can't decide which one I like more, it really depends if you prefer a fantasy or a sci-fi setting, and I like them both.

Pros:

+ better graphics and sounds than in HoS
+ more focused mission-based gameplay helps keeping a good pace
+ missions are not repetitive, objectives are varied and you need different approaches
+ more character types, with lots of possibilities for talent/gear customization
+ extensive tech tree that makes talent choice much less obvious than in HoS

(Very minor) Cons:

- as in HoS, music is mainly made of loops; there are some brilliant tunes among the lot, but also some that you'd wish to skip (but you can't, unless you exit the mission and reload)  (you can check my Extended Soundtrack mod if you wish, look for it in the Steam forum)
- unlike in HoS, the story isn't a very important part of the game, even if it shares the setting and the world lore of other games by the same developer (the Star Traders series).
- a bit shorter than HoS

Overall the game is great, and you should play it if you like turn based combat. Don't expect XCOM (I mean the old one), here there's a story that enfolds, and missions are pre-scripted. It's very rare that I keep playing a game after I've finished it once, and it happened with this one.

I also have to say that some of the few negative reviews insist on the fact that it's a mobile port or that it has a mobile feel, and have put really little time in actually playing the game. I've never played a game on a mobile device so I can't judge, all I know is that if you focus on the game's qualities you shouldn't really care if it's a port or not.

reviewText:
Suit Up for Tactical Greatness !
Templar Battleforce is a very engaging and well thought out turn based Tactical RPG. It is a bit light on the roleplaying aspect but the action is amazing and has a ruleset that blows away the simple but punishing nature of games like the newest XCom's hit/miss mechanics. You will not find frustration by making the right decisions just to have your men screw up your tactical approach. But failure will come with bad choices or just a lack of battlefield visibility that you did not get, aka you can feel good that your loss is your fault in this game and not the dice. I have put together a couple of lists of things you can do in this game and why it is cool.

Before I get into the details, I'll cut straight to the chase with some stuff that wow'ed me:

A scout who does not have to be long ranged but I can use his massive movement to sneak up and melee troops down quickly or have him cripple enemy movement long-distance before my soldiers mop him up with overwatch fire
Overwatch fire from soldiers is a big field I set down where enemies who move into the square get shot ( for free, no action on my soldiers part) each time they move through the field, but they also clear a path for other enemies to go through, so you might have to have a couple of overwatch fields to get everyone, but the enemy does try to use this to their advantage.
I personally fell in love with the Hydra class the minute he set half of the battlefield on fire and I saw xenos running through them getting torched, only to fall to my overwatch fire or weakly attack my captain and then get slain by his free counter-attack.
Tactical Character Customization    Characters are outfitted by purchasing ranks in a tree tech system. It is a tree that splits each of the 8 classes into 3 distinct trees. You get points to buy them after each mission. This alone gives you the ability to customize and play whatever squad you want, in a way that you want. You can go crazy with a super tough melee oriented squad, or go sneaky long-range scouts, or just blow up the whole battlefield with Pyromaniac Hydras and grenade slinging soldiers.
Combat involves both melee and ranged and both are very good and compliment each other. Melee and ranged are both about positioning your men right. Since this is turn based, but has reaction type skills like Overwatch in it, you want to make it appealing for enemies to engage your melee who can counter-attack them, through your ranged overwatch fields. This is very fun to setup fire lanes and watch enemies fall before your organization.
Combat is about escalation and management of your forces and the enemies. Each map usually involves you trying to cut off the enemy forces before they outnumber you too greatly ( or your suits start frying your men because each action builds up heat that can damage you if it gets to high from using it). You can counter this by controlling choke points but the cool mechanic is that you can control tactical points to bring in more templars whose abilities might really help you out - a hydra to ignite the whole battlefield or another soldier to setup more overwatch lanes...or perhaps a stealthy scout to infiltrate and lock down another area where the xenos are pouring in from. This becomes a game within the game in a way.
Rules System that is explained in game so you don't need to wiki everything
Combat resolution is a system of D10 dice rolls made in game that are compared to your opponents opposing dice rolls. This distributed average of hit and misses makes sure that your characters and the enemies are not just getting lucky or unlucky.
There are no obvious dump stats when you level up your templars, the game does its best to make every stat important. Aggressive damage stats like Quickness also give you defense bonuses, stats like tactical influence how good your buffs from your men are but also give you critical hit advantages.
There are no crazy instant win abilities or stats. Every ability and stat plays into each other very well and makes you build a team of fully functional warriors who need each other.
I know this was a long review, but damn, this game is great and I feel like I am only in the beginning still after 15 hours. I definitely look forward to conquering this game and then moving onto higher difficulties with a much better strategy.

reviewText:
Templar Battleforce is one of those games that had no right to be as good as it is. It's a game of dizzying depth and what it lacks in raw graphics it makes up for in gameplay.

If anyone played the Space Hulk videogame and felt it lacking then Templar Battleforce is the answer. It plays very much like a mix of Space Hulk (both the boardgame and the videogame) and X-COM, though it's by no means a clone of either of these games. Templar Battleforce brings to the table many new features such as 'Heat' for your Templars, an opposite of HP that means every move you make or action you take will put your Templar one step closer to overheating. The mechanic forces you to give your men a rest every few turns or risk taking unwanted damage over time. On top of that certain battlefield have Tactical Points which can be captured by you or the Xenos. Once these points have been captured you can spend the SP they generate to call in more soldiers or ordance, or upgrade your team. Any recruits you call in that survive the battle will become veterans, and can be deployed in every battle from there on.

From a fantastic lore to fantastic gameplay to rather decent music Templar Battleforce is well worth the price that it's being sold for.

reviewText:
Templar Battleforce is a turn-based squad tactic game. Your units gain experience and requistion/technology points in missions. The more side objective you achieve and xenos you kill the more xp and rp you get. With xp you can level your units, with requisition you can buy new skills, classes and weapons, powerfull relics in the requisition tree. The tech tree is rather large.

There are 8 classes: Captain, Hydra, Neptune,  Berserk, Soldier, Engineer, Scout and Paladin.

The classes have different equipment and skills. Your progression choices on attributes when leveling have impact on the gameplay. A unit with high fortitude and melee skill is good in melee as you can aspect. But you can also decide to try different builds. A standart bearer with excellent party buffs for your captain? Or a soldier with high grenade ability and melee skills? It is your choice.

The requisition system is interesting and motivates to get more rp to get better equipment and classes. Some are even essential for progress in the game. The paladin as healer or the engineer for capturing strongholds in the level, where you can get reinforcements.

The tactical gameplay is very good. You have a little rng here, because every actions success is based on dice throws. But if you invest xp intelligently into your units you get nearly 100% chances on attacks and up to 60% block evade for incoming attacks. It is possible to create 'useless' units, if you invest wrong, But you can respec your units anytime in the hq to prepare for missions on normal difficulty. The AI behaves human like. It does not circumvent your overwatch field, it is not omniscent and makes errors. A human player could not know where you place your traps or overwatch so it does not cheat to win. The AI has many units to make the missions more interesting. After 10 missions i had killed 500 aliens. More then in any other turn based tactic game i played before. The missions can get quite difficult when you are slow and not focused on your objective. After all you are fighting against hordes of aliens, stopping and resting will get you overwhelmed quickly. The missions are quite interesting and different. Some times you have to escort a bomb carrier into the heart of an alien cruiser or defend a bridgehead for some time. Or you have to kill a boss while being attacked by waves of aliens. Killing the boss will win the mission.

Your units have movement points and action points to spent. You should move before using action points, because any left movement points are spent when you use your action points.

The grafics and sounds are adequate. They are 2d, every unit is animated. Unfortunately there is no movement range indicator for enemies, so you have to learn the movement patterns of the different enemy units. Most have 6 movement range like your units. Do not expect Xcom remake like grafics.

If you like the old star quest or space hulk boardgames this game is made for you. It is space hulk on steroids, with tech tree and a roleplaying stat system and an interesting atmosphere and story.

I encountered many bugs but not one software bug in this game. Performance is flawless. Very nice product.

I am not a fan of pointy review score, but i would give this game a 10/10. My personal game of the year.

Have a nice day

reviewText:
In a few words, Templar Battleforce is a 2D XCOM set in a backdrop that is heavily inspired by Warhammer 40k. It is somewhat rough around the edges but is surprisingly easy to get into if you have a general idea of what to expect.

The core tactical combat gameplay is very well done and even exceeds games like XCOM in some areas such as flexibility and variety. While the internal mechanics of combat suffer from the opaqueness of the dice rolls system and of the damage mitigation formula, the game offsets this with ample toolips and a set of starting missions which guide new players through all they need to know to enjoy the game. Extra praise is deserved for both the tooltips and tutorials as these two elements are rarely well done in indie games and are often quite mediocre in AAA releases.

Combat itself is familiarly intuitive and draws much of its allure from the fairly deep customization options and progression available. First off you have a sort of tech tree which controls the pool of equipment, active abilities, and recruitable templar classes available. Every templar in your band belongs to a class which defines which active abilities are available and which equipment can be equipped. In addition to equipment and talents (active abilities), every templar has two sets of defining statistics which can be increased by one point each level. You will end up customizing talents, equipment, and attributes for each templar every time he levels up which will be every 1-2 missions. This is so since you can freely respec any templar between missions and you will want to do this when new abilities or equipment become available, which happens almost after every mission depending on how you choose to progress the tech tree. This opens ups the ability to experiment freely with your squad build and keeps you from worrying too much about planning your progression ahead of time.

I was also very happy with the mission design so far (about 10 missions in). The length of each mission is right on target with about 30 mins on average and the overall pacing is excellent so far. The time I’m spending in mission and out of mission leveling my army is at a good ratio to prevent being fatigued with either aspect. The missions themselves don’t drag out with most missions aiming for around 15 turns on average to complete which keeps each turn and what you do in it very significant. The heat mechanic plays an important role here. Heat builds up from using abilities and moving and decreases a small amount each turn and will decrease a lot in a turn if no or almost no actions are taken during that turn. Maxing out on heat will start causing hitpoint damage to the templar so this helps keep the action tense makes you consider every action you take or don’t take during a turn.

I have a few small gripes with the game which affect my enjoyment of it in very limited ways. No ability to change keybindings is regrettable but not critical since the default scheme is workable if somewhat inconvenient. The way vision works could use improvement as your templars can only seem to see 5 squares away which can lead to very awkward ambushes. Enemies can attack the same turn they spawn which is annoying but since they don’t spawn in packs, for the most part, this is nowhere near as big an issue as it was in XCOM. There is plenty of room for the UI to be improved and enhanced with such features as moving the camera via mouse screen edge scrolling, highlighting interactable elements on mouseover, indicating which squares either your unit or an enemy unit can move to this turn or the enemy's next turn. The Devs have indicated that some of these fetures, edge scrolling in particular, will be added in future updates.

This is a game I would highly recommend to anyone who enjoys turn-based tactical RPGs in the style of the recent XCOM or going further back to Temple of Elemental Evil and Pool of Radiance. The story is very adequate for a game where the story is arguably not the main focus and works very well to build up the right atmosphere of tension and heroics and this is a type of game that benefits greatly from having that kind of backdrop. The ample depth of progression available for your “army” and each templar along with way the game encourages experimentation will keep most players hooked.

I originally picked this game up just because it was a turn based strategy game, and I love games that reming me of the many hours I put into Fire Emblem.

Sound: My first instinct here is to say that it has an 8-bit or 16-bit feel. Because the theme, it has space, steampunk, and a bit medieval history. It blends all the themes and their sounds, and makes for a very nice feel to add to the game.

Graphics: This game could have been on the old Nintendo or Sega systems back in the 90's. For the younger generation, this game is probably awful looking, but I just love it. The nostalgia of playing a game that could have been a game  from my youth is just great. The colors of the Templars and the other factions are simple but feel right. The templars are a rustic metal, while the Xeno seem like they're straight out of a circuit board.

reviewText:
Templar Battleforce is a top-down, turn-based strategy title evoking memories of Laser Squad (forerunner of the original UFO: Enemy Unknown).

The game is essentially a linked series of missions interspersed with squad and tech management, plus a smidge of storytelling.  The units under your control, the eponymous Templars, are not entirely dissimilar to WH40k Space Marines, being humans piloting suits of battle armour that augment their abilities.  The twist here is that rather than having a concept like 'gene-seed', a Templar's memories and experiences are passed down through their bloodline across generations.

Anyway, enough of the fluff.  The meat of the game - the tactical battles is competently done; movement and combat is handled via a variation of the time-honoured action point system and works intuitively.  Most missions seem to have a turn goal - completion of the objective within this will bestow extra experience, and this mechanic - coupled with a large sprinkling of risk/reward secondary objectives and tactical points to capture -  can lead to some nail-biting mission climaxes.

There are excellent customisation options available for your Templars in between missions too, an RPG-lite skill and talent progression system for them to work through and  a very detailed tech tree which you unlock parts of by using the 'resource points' tallied up at the end of each battle.  Contained within the tech tree (which in terms of presentation reminds me of Sword of the Stars 1) are many weapons (some unique), abilites and miscellaneous items all of which allow for many varied takes on a Templar squad's makeup.

Graphically the game is serviceable and has improved with recent patches.  The audio is functional but nothing to write home about.  If I had one niggle it would simply be the relatively minor suggestion that the game lacks a little polish - there are points at which grammatical/spelling errors crop up in some of the story text for example and while I freely acknowledge that these are far from game-breaking, they do nonetheless pull me out of my 'zone' in the game and bring me back to reality with a bump.

All things considered (including the fantastic support Trese brothers continue to lavish on the game) I would heartilty recommend this title to anyone who enjoys turn-based squad level combat.  It's probably the closest we'll ever get to a genuine turn-based WH40k game, yet it does have its own distinct and well-developed lore.  Blend this with some brilliant research and management options then ask yourself - what more could you want for the price?

reviewText:
The game is well worth the price, and even more so if on sale.

As cheesy as the word Battleforce can be, the title is quite engaging and fun for those that enjoy strategy and turn based games.
A dice system akin to WH40K and DnD is used to calculate combat values and statistics, while gameplay wise it performs similar to xcom on a grid system. All units are limited by seperate action points and movement points while every command or use of an ability generates Heat, that limits continuos actions.
Both melee and ranged combat are availible and the game pushes you to explore and develop your own loadouts for each member.
after each mission you are awarded experience points for your Templars and Requisition points to develop your technology trees that in turn unlock new weapons, armor and even units.

While the story is not the most intruiging, it is fresh and simple enough to add to the game. Every level is mostly unique with different objectives, layouts and aproaches to them that create a scale of replayability and keep gamers interested to continue.

As any early access title, the game does have a few bugs and confusing aspects that arent explained very well in it's library of explainations. Save for weapon types, new weapons are not visually different on the templar as well as armor. Radial zones used for targeting enemies are often misrepresented and AOE abilities must be guessed and judged without indication.

Overall, the fun of wiping out Xeno scum and thrusting my Captain ♥♥♥♥-middle into the fray of battle overpowers any complaints.

10/10 for random xenos spawning in the middle of my squad after ending turn.

reviewText:
A tactics game done right.

Here's the game in a nutshell: you lead a squad of totally not Space Marine Terminators in repurposed industrial suits who fight endless swarms of totally not tyranids aboard spaceships.

Your templars can level up, use different gear, be customised, etc - you know the drill.
The game mechanics are a cross between space hulk (action points, swarms of deadly melee aliens coming from everywhere, overwatch) and generic tactics game features (use of stealth, different classes, melee is actually viable).
New gear and skills are unlocked through big huge requisition tree.

Graphics is... okay, I'd say and music is scarce. There is a plot, but it's not important. All you need to know is that YOU GUIDE VALOROUS BATTLE-BROTHERS IN A NEVERENDING CRUSADE OF PURGATION AGAINST VILE XENO SCUM FOR THE GLORY OF THE MANKIND. And almost all of these totally not WH40K terms are said by your squad leader at some moments.

All of this might give you an impression that the game is a bland low-budget space hulk clone.
And you will be very wrong, because it is AWESOME hardcore tactics with deep gameplay, which only draws some inspiration from aforementioned space hulk. And did I say that the game is hard? I mean really hard, as in your squad can be wiped on normal during tutorial" hard.

reviewText:
TEMPLAR BATTLEFORCE has a very strong tactical table top character. From the color rich style of the units and the board style maps to the Warhammer 40k heroic writing style it all gives off a very flamboyant grim science fiction feel with undertones of Fasa's Battletech universe. It has a very detailed leveling and character design system with tons of skills to unlock not to mention all sorts of futuristic upgrades to the multiple weapons systems such as scanners, heat disipating improvements, energy and physical shields, heavy weapons and melee weapon upgrades, enemy detection and stealth avoidence addons etc etc.

The enemies are pretty much Tyranids in behaviour and looks which is done perfectly creating a xeno terror out of your worst H.R. Giger nightmares. Things really get tense when they start to increase and swarm in numbers. They definitely test my strategic skill as i figure out if its best to fight, flee or repair my suit among many other choices. There are plenty of buffs like shields to decrease damage, a commander inspiring skill to motivate units in combat, terrain which increases defense and attack bonuses, overwatch mode, etc etc.

Incredibly well done game which for turn based feels very fast paced and hectic. The music is also quite atmospheric capturing a mix of gloom and heroic persistence to fight on against impossible odds to shatter the darkness and bring forth a piercing beam of light transmitting hope into the mentally crushed and spiritually hopeless.

TEMPLAR BATTLEFORCE a tour de force of epic warfare in a brutal universe of unrelenting all consuming terror. If you value your gaming happiness you will purchase this sacred work with its devastating armaments of annihilation and praise the ancestors for the battle bliss to come!

reviewText:
Well i have been trying to think of a review for this game for a long while. I have even been encouraged to do one by the developers and i genuinely think they take criticism on the nose and act on it. They're good developers, i like them. Though as a disclaimer i use to like the BoE (Battle of Empire) devs too until they screwed up so....Take that with a grain of salt i guess.

Anyway on with the review.

For starters i'll look at it's aesthetic and how nice it looks, mostly because that's what i see first on the store page. And it can be very, very misleading sometimes, for better or worse. So how does the game look? it looks like a top down 2D strategy game (as you can probably guess). When actually playing the game it looks pretty good, it looks how it does on the store page and even has a few nice little details here and there, it looks nice for what it is. If i had a complaint it would be that i think they could go even further with the details but we're talking tiny, usually not noticable things here, it looks fine as it is.

I couldn't really think of anywhere else to put this so it'll tie the graphics and gameplay segments together. It looks like Warhammer 40K and XCOM had a baby. It shares the gameplay of XCOM (with a top down 2D view) and even the perma death (at normal difficulty and above only, i think). The Warhammer 40K part comes in just from the lore and its general look. This, keep in mind, is not a rip off of either game and it only looks like it was inspired from it. The gameplay itself is your standard squad based turn based strategy game in the same vein as XCOM. Most of it actually feels a lot like the XCOM except with some functional differences. There isn't any cover (sadly) but there are tiles that boost your defense or your weapon range. There is melee combat as well which opens up a few new possibilities. The level design is pretty good as well, layouts are good, squad loadouts and levelling up is also pretty nice, it lets you play how you want for the most part.

Audio is fantastic, i love the soundtrack for the game, the weapons sound a little weak (in my opinion) but other than the plasma rifle's its ok for the most part. Not a lot to say here as its all ok at least and fantastic at best.

Bugs, glitches and optimisation. I haven't noticed any bugs, i don't think i've even seen reports about them or any wide spread problems on systems. The optimisation is pretty good. It shouldn't be hard to get a game like this optimised due to how little it actually uses of my system but hey, worth mentioning.

Extra comments or thing's i think should be said: the game is pretty awesome, i finished it in around 20 hours. Will add any more edits or thoughts as time goes on and i play it more.

reviewText: Overall a solid game and good value for the money at the initial release but needs fine tuning. Thankfully did not enounter any bugs on my first play through (demanding difficulty). Balance could use some improvement. None of the maps felt particularly challenging, so much as occasionally tedious. Some levels are near impossible to complete in the target number of turns (if you approach them with no prior knowledge) and can spiral into runaway heat as you search for the right order to activate switches. Once know the correct path to take for routing power / unlocking doors, they are easy. These sequence should really be randomized and the maps balanced accordingly. Other than that, most maps can generally be rushed in half the number of target turns or less. MP is the single most important attribute. Buffed scouts with 12+ MP will wreck many maps. Beat the end boss in 7 turns on first try (target 30)... felt like the easiest map in the game. RNG can be silly with the map initialization. Sometimes you spawn a single low level creature on first turn, other times you spawn a whole group of powerful mobs, which makes the idea of playing on Ironman completely unappealing. Haven't tried to replay as a second lineage. Hopefully replay will encourage more complex builds and incorporate more variety in mobs in terms of abilities and tactics and not just faster spawning / higher stats. Also hoping that end game content when it is released will introduce new gameplay since right now every map feels like either a scout blitz or engineer march.

Everyone can sympathise with the fact that there is always that cousin or sibling who just happens to overshadow you in every little thing you do - just like X-COM overshadows this little beauty.

(FYI anyone who saw the word 'templar' in the name expecting to see Altair in space.....no....just no...)

First things first - Its not X-COM. Similar pretence. Similar style. But not X-COM. It is a great game with a well thought out story and gripping mechanics. The retro style graphics gives a wave of nostaliga and the difficulty levels ensure all players can have whatever level challenge they wish. The turn based system is excellent and merged with a time limit it ensures you cannot slowly (and safely) crawl through a level. The 'heat' mechanic is a breath of fresh air and you are forced to play sensibly to ensure your templars do not overheat and turn into metal burritos.

There is limited replayability factor, and there is additionally nothing new with this 'alien invasion' story and the turn based mechanics. But that doesnt detract from the fact that Templar Battleforce hits the spot and succeeds to add its mark to the turn based genre.

I would seriously reccomend this to anyone who enjoys turn based strategy games. It is certainly worth the small price to play this little gem.

reviewText:
This is a very addictive strategy title with deep customization, an interesting universe and impressively clever A.I!
The major difficulties with the product I have are entirely aesthetic: the art style and color scheme is a little garish and the music is forgetable 'epic' type which repeats too often.
But that said you can tell this was built from the ground up and the passion and complexity it not only admirable it makes the whole experience richer knowing the creators cared about this, tested it, added to it and continue to listen to player comments and make updates to the day!
If you're a fan of Warhammer 40K, especially Space Hulk, this game is like that mixed with some of my favorite aspects of X-Com (good old overwatch!) Total Anhiliation (capture supply points and deploy a customized squad) and even Path of Exile (expansive skill tree and you can equip armor and weapons as well as artifacts).
It looks a little wonky but that's only because I believe you aren't looking at prefab assets stolen from other proejcts and clearly a giant studio wasn't behind this. But I was looking for a long lasting, entertaining, strategic game with RPG elements and squad mechanics and this has filled that void admirably. You will rarely feel as fullfilled as an entire charging horde of aliens gets cut to shreds by a line of snipers and turrets.

I'm sorry, I can't recommend this game at this stage, not for 10 €.

I played only a couple of missions, but I already can tell that:

- it feels unpolished in some areas, for example I had to turn off music after 2 minutes, because it sounded like it's the same 15 second looped over and over again
- I can see mobile roots of the game. That doesn't have to be something bad, but it is in this case. For example UI is lacking. There are tooltips, but they do not have all the information. There are actions your templars can do (attacks, buffs etc.). Tooltips only tell you the cost of the action, but details about what it actually does (for example, that this attack has +x damage) are not available there. You have to right click on the button to get more detailed information. Overal the interface is not very friendly.
- the game is slow. And I don't mean that my PC is struggling or that I get low FPS - it's just that enemy is taking his time. It's a littley funny, because there is this option to change speed of AI turn to high and it turns off animations. That would be nice, but in practice they take almost as long even without the animations (enemy would run to your unit, stop, think, attack, your templar would attack back, enemy would stop, think, attack etc. it really takes a lot of time).


I do think the game has potential, so if you are not sure, remember you can try and ask for refund if you don't like it (which I'm going to do now).

reviewText:
Clunky, unresponsive controls.  Because there is no movement range indicator, it's a matter of guesswork to see how far each templar can move each turn.  Enemies also don't highlight when you scroll over them, making it difficult to know when the game has received your input, resulting in lots of frustrating and unsatisfying over-clicking.  Which wouldn't be so much of an issue if the controls weren't otherwise laggy and unresponsive.  They make it feel like you're playing the game in an emulator window.

Painfully slow cutscenes with lots of dead air and amateurish attack animations also make this game very difficult for me to get into.  Also, I don't know if anyone else has this problem, but the bottom of the screen where the attack buttons are gets cut off for me in fullscreen mode.

Cool idea, bad execution.  Don't waste the $10.
